verses.text: God stands in the assembly of God; He judges among the gods.
verses.comment: This verse uses 'gods' ('elohim'), likely referring to human judges or rulers, not deities. Jesus references this passage in John 10:34, showing how true authority comes from God. Catholics understand the assembly as a divine council, prefiguring the Church as the mystical body where God presides over His people.

verses.text: How long will you judge unjustly and show favoritism to the wicked? Selah.
verses.comment: God rebukes corrupt judges for partiality. 'Selah' prompts reflection. Catholic social teaching stresses justice and care for the powerless, a reflection of God's righteous judgment.

verses.text: Defend the weak and the orphan; do justice to the afflicted and the destitute.
verses.comment: Command to care for the vulnerable recalls the Mosaic Law (Deut. 24:17). The Church continues this mission via works of mercy, living out Christ’s command to love the least.

verses.text: Rescue the weak and the needy; deliver them from the hand of the wicked.
verses.comment: God’s justice involves active intervention. Catholic doctrine emphasizes social justice and protecting human dignity, echoing Christ’s mission (Luke 4:18-19).

verses.text: They do not know, nor do they understand; they walk about in darkness. All the foundations of the earth are shaken.
verses.comment: Ignorant leaders destabilize society. Catholics believe true understanding comes from God’s revelation, safeguarded in the apostolic tradition of the Church.

verses.text: I said, 'You are gods; all of you are sons of the Most High.'
verses.comment: Human rulers are called 'gods' as God’s representatives. Jesus quotes this in John 10:34 to reveal His divinity and authority. Catholic theology holds that, through Christ, believers become adopted children of God (theosis/sanctification).

verses.text: But you shall die like men, and fall like one of the princes.
verses.comment: Even those with authority are subject to death. This foreshadows the need for salvation beyond earthly power, ultimately realized in Christ’s resurrection and the Church’s promise of eternal life.

verses.text: Arise, O God, judge the earth; for You shall inherit all nations.
verses.comment: God is appealed to as the universal judge who reigns over all nations. This prophetic call is fulfilled in Christ’s kingship and the universal mission of the Catholic Church (Ps. 2:8; Matt. 28:19).
